title: Trump Administration Imposed More Postelection Sanctions Than Recent Administrations
summary: A surge in postelection designations could complicate foreign policy for the Biden administration. The Trump administration issued a flurry of sanctions after Election Day, a move that could complicate foreign policy for the Biden administration, sanctions policy observers said.

title: Cuomo Implores Biden Administration to Boost Covid-19 Vaccine Supplies
summary: New York will keep running out of shots without influx, governor says. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo called on the Biden administration to ramp up production of the Covid-19 vaccine, warning that New York will exhaust its allotted doses on a weekly basis for the foreseeable future.

title: Student Loan Payment, Eviction Pauses Extended
summary: Executive orders are signed by new president to maintain protections from economic hardships caused by Covid-19 pandemic. On his first day in office, President Biden signed a range of executive actions including two that will affect the financial lives of millions of Americans.

title: Biden, Faith and Tolerance
summary: An opportunity for our new president to stand behind his words.. Unity, God and country were the themes of President Joe Biden's Wednesday inauguration. For those who treasure the First Amendment's guarantee of religious liberty and fear that much of the political left seeks to drive religion from the public square, the day's events likely came as a welcome relief.

title: Florida Ophthalmologist With Ties to Sen. Menendez Among Those Granted Clemency by Trump
summary: Salomon Melgen among more than a dozen in health care industry who received late-hour pardons or commutations. A Florida eye doctor convicted of defrauding Medicare of $73 million got a break when President Trump commuted the man's sentence hours before vacating the White House.

title: Full List of Trump's Pardons, Commutations
summary: Outgoing president pardoned 74 individuals, commuted sentences of 70 others before leaving office. Former President Donald Trumpissued 144 grants of clemency before leaving office, pardoning 74 people and commuting the sentences of 70 others.

title: Trump's Pardons-Good, Bad and Ugly
summary: On the last-minute clemency list, Steve Bannon stands out.. On his way out the door Wednesday, President Trump granted a long list of pardons and commutations, and it's a mix of the reasonable, the unseemly and the egregious. Here's looking at you, Steve Bannon.

title: Biden's Keystone Pipeline Kill
summary: On his first day he insults Canada and ends thousands of jobs.. President Biden issued a blizzard of executive orders on his first day in office, including a diktat to revoke the permit for the Keystone XL pipeline. This is a slap at Canada, and it sends a message to investors that playing by U.S. rules provides no immunity from arbitrary political whim.

title: Joe Biden's Unity Address
summary: National healing doesn't require agreement on one point of view.. Whatever their partisan affiliation, all Americans can take pride in Wednesday's inaugural proceedings for President Joe Biden. The peaceful transfer of power from one party to another is a sign of underlying democratic strength no matter our current political distemper.

title: Subdued Inauguration Lacks Usual Crowds
summary: Resume Subscription. WASHINGTON-Inauguration Day unfolded like no other before it as tens of thousands of troops guarded the nation's capital and Americans watched the scaled-down events on computers and televisions.

title: Beijing Fills the Mideast Vacuum
summary: China's projection of power isn't only a regional concern. It will eventually pose a threat to the U.S.. The Biden administration's Middle East policy will reportedly focus on rejoining the Iran nuclear deal and renewing Israeli-Palestinian negotiations. This could undermine key allies in Israel and Saudi Arabia while ignoring a core geopolitical challenge that few in Washington are addressing: growing Chinese influence in the Middle East.

title: The Republican Future Starts Now
summary: How to keep working-class Trump voters while winning back support in the suburbs?. President Joe Biden's inauguration marks not only a new administration's beginning but also a new chapter for the loyal opposition.

title: America Needs a National Identity Card
summary: It could solve the problems of voting, immigration and Covid-19 vaccination.. Americans don't like the idea of a national identity card. But in an era of intense controversies over election integrity and illegal immigration, it is time to rethink the subject.

title: If Corporate Diversity Works, Show Me the Money
summary: Nasdaq wants to mandate wider representation on its companies' boards but has little proof of the benefits.. Corporate directors are called on to do a few important things: Hire a CEO and oversee management, provide strategic direction, protect and promote the interests of investors, and ensure the company's books are honest. Now, many claim, directors should also represent the country's demographics.

title: Joe Biden's Super State
summary: The Covid vaccination mess calls to mind the catastrophic rollout of ObamaCare.. Voter concern over the public handling of the Covid-19 pandemic is one reason Joe Biden is the 46th president of the United States. Translation: Mr. Biden is the dog that caught the Covid bus. Now what?

title: 'Fundamentals' Review: The Simplicity of Abundance
summary: The cosmos is so vast as to defy the imagination. So too the atomic realm, with its inner vastness. Yet the 'ingredients' are few.. It is no easy thing to describe the properties of dark matter, or the latest loop in string theory, or the functions of the Higgs boson particle. The study of physics has advanced to a state that feels remote from everyday experience and even, at times, from normal intelligibility. Luckily, a cluster of what might be called literary physicists-among them, Carlo Rovelli, Brian Greene and Alan Lightman-have found ways of rendering the thorny concepts of modern physics into lucid, and often lyrical, language.

title: United Airlines Offers Grim Outlook but Seeks to Rebuild
summary: Airline said it plans to recover in coming years with revenue from future travel and cost-cutting. United Airlines Holdings Inc. on Wednesday said it expects the coronavirus pandemic will continue to weigh on travel demand this year as the airline turns its focus to rebuilding itself.

title: Now Isn't the Time to Let Up on Cancer Screening
summary: Resume Subscription. While we celebrate that the death rate from cancer in the U.S. dropped 2.4% from 2017 to 2018 and that the cancer mortality rate has fallen 31% since its peak in 1991 ("Cancer Death Rate in 2018 Fell By the Largest-Ever Yearly Amount," U.S. News, Jan. 13), Covid-19 is having a negative effect on cancer prevention and early detection.

title: New Penn Station Is a Catalyst for Renewal
summary: There is a once-in-a-century opportunity to unlock this region's upside potential, including New York City proper, by unifying the transit network centered on a rethought and rebuilt above-ground Penn Station.. Michael J. Lewis's "Upping the Waiting Game-Moynihan Train Hall, the expansion of Penn Station, imbues rail travel with some grandeur" (Arts in Review, Jan. 14) affirms the importance of proactivity and innovation when skeptics are writing cities off.

title: Europeans Clash With Pfizer, BioNTech Over Vaccine Deliveries
summary: Governments allege shortfall in deliveries is endangering their immunization campaigns. Tension is rising between European authorities and Pfizer Inc. and BioNTech SE after officials said the companies had unexpectedly cut their deliveries of Covid-19 vaccines and put their immunization schedules at risk.

title: Many Are Happy to Pay a Bit More for Clean Energy
summary: There are many who will happily pay more-to encourage alternative sources, to put long-term impact ahead of short-term savings and to better reflect total costs associated with production, distribution, use, etc.. Jinjoo Lee ("Peak Oil? Not This Year. Or This Decade," Exchange, Jan. 9) apparently decided everyone is interested in the sticker price above all else when blithely stating, "Nobody likes paying more for energy."

title: Boeing's Chiefs Had Eyes on the Wrong Ball
summary: The core problem at Boeing is systemic and lies primarily with the decision makers at the corporate level.. Andy Pasztor and Andrew Tangel's "Boeing's Failure To Launch" (Exchange, Jan. 16) notes that " Boeing declined to make any executives available for interviews." There is your problem.

title: Time for Companies to End All Political Contributions
summary: "Companies Suspend Political Funding" (U.S. News, Jan. 11) brings many of us to say: "About time!". "Companies Suspend Political Funding" (U.S. News, Jan. 11) brings many of us to say: "About time!"

title: Biden Declares Democracy Has Survived, Unity Possible
summary: The 46th president faces one of the toughest tests as he tells the nation it can pick up the pieces and move forward. Over the last five decades, Joe Biden endured multiple personal tragedies and saw his political obituary written over and over again-yet always found a way to pick up the pieces and move forward.

title: Joe Biden's Inauguration Speech With Full Annotated Transcript
summary: Resume Subscription. This is an experimental format. The annotated transcript was created using automated speech to text technology, to generate a first draft of the transcription. Editors then proof-read and corrected the transcript, and annotated key sections with additional context and insights.

title: Stocks Hit Records on Upbeat Earnings
summary: Dow, Nasdaq, S&P at new highs as investors parse results from Netflix, Procter & Gamble, others. Rising shares of Netflix and other technology companies pushed major stock indexes to fresh records Wednesday, reviving Wall Street's appetite for growth stocks.

title: Abroad at Home: Virtual Vatican
summary: An interactive tour of the empty Vatican Museums offers the chance to experience the Sistine Chapel and other Renaissance treasures without the crowds.. Typically, the Vatican Museums are a source of both pleasure and frustration. Amid the throngs, it can be impossible to achieve any kind of contemplative state to allow real absorption of their many artistic treasures. While we are limited to armchair travel because of Covid-19, the impressive virtual visits offered by the Vatican Museums create the pleasurable sensation of seeing these typically crowded halls all alone. Digital tourism also allows you to see a few of the many rooms normally closed to the public, such as the Niccoline Chapel with frescoes by Fra Angelico (1395-1455).

title: Inflation-Protected Treasury Yields Hold Near Record Lows
summary: Investors increasingly expect higher inflation, but not Fed rate increases, analysts say. Investors are hanging on to bonds that protect against inflation even as they sell other U.S. government debt, a sign many trust the Federal Reserve to hold interest rates steady even if the economy picks up steam.

title: Pop Star (Thursday Crossword, January 21)
In Portland, a Concrete and Steel Home That Refuses to Conform
summary: Jamie Baldwin and his late husband, David Carter, tore down a Craftsman-style property and built a contemporary house in its place. It takes a certain pluck to tear down a 1904 Craftsman in the middle of an understated neighborhood and replace it with a $4 million, rectangular, four-story, white-glazed terra-cotta, concrete and steel building twice the size of the old, traditional houses around it.

title: Here's How the Modern Manager Is Changing
summary: The boss of the future will likely be more of a coach and less of a dictator. Cost-cutting measures first implemented during the financial crisis led to fewer managers and more direct reports. The role is still evolving today. The bosses of the future are likely to be coaches rather than dictators and excel at fostering collaboration. Age and industry experience may be less of a prerequisite for these jobs. Here are three ways the characteristics of successful bosses are shifting to match changes in the working world.

title: Fashion at Biden-Harris Inauguration Showcases Commitment to American Designers
summary: At today's ceremony, the work of American designers ruled supreme, from President Joe Biden's Ralph Lauren suit to Vice President Kamala Harris's Christopher John Rogers purple outfit. Lady Gaga and J. Lo performed in more extravagant fashions from Schiaparelli Couture and Chanel. THE AMERICAN fashion industry is suddenly abuzz again. For today's inauguration, President Joe Biden, first lady Dr. Jill Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris and second gentleman Douglas Emhoff have all chosen to wear the work of American designers or labels, including Ralph Lauren, Christopher John Rogers and Markarian. "These moments on Day One are so important for an industry that's been so hard hit and impacted by the pandemic," said Steven Kolb, chief executive officer of the Council of Fashion Designers of America. "By wearing these American designers, they're not only boosting the business of those individuals, but they're really boosting the $373 billion industry...We have a new administration that clearly is welcoming and wants to be supportive of our industry."

title: Can the Nugget Couch Really Keep Quarantined Kids Entertained?
summary: Pent-up children can reconfigure chic modular furniture-like the pandemic best-seller the Nugget-into forts and palaces, saving parents sanity. WHEN RACHEL GEER'S kids started slam-dunking a basketball into a nearby plastic hoop with the sofa as their launchpad, she suppressed the urge to scold. After all, they'd been stuck inside for 10 months. Luckily for the Chapel Hill, N.C., business analyst, the abused couch was a Nugget, the sort of modular sofa designed for such debauchery that interiors pros are recommending to families with children.

title: Poet Amanda Gorman Has Star Turn at Biden Inauguration
summary: Youngest inauguration poet reads poem written after the siege of the U.S. Capitol. Inaugural poet Amanda Gorman brought former presidents, lawmakers and dignitaries to their feet as she read a poem that aimed to inspire after the Jan. 6 siege of the U.S. Capitol. She delivered it standing outside that very building.

title: What to Watch: In Netflix's 'Lupin,' a Dapper Thief Plots a Heist-and Revenge
summary: Plus, a critically acclaimed film, 'The White Tiger,' and more films and series to add to your queue. Netflix is on a roll. Even up against a pandemic and increased competition from some of the world's biggest media companies, Netflix managed to grow its rolls to more than 200 million subscribers. This week's streaming selections speak to the breadth of the service's programming ambitions: from the critically acclaimed ("The White Tiger") and the family adventure flick ("We Can Be Heroes") to international series popular with American audiences ("Lupin").

title: Trump Pardons Business Figures, Financiers
summary: A former Google engineer and ex-CEOs are among the many who got last-minute presidential pardons. In one of his last acts as president, Donald Trump issued dozens of pardons and commutations, including for some notable figures in the worlds of business and finance. (Click here for a full list of Mr. Trump's pardons.)

title: Restaurants Get Sales Lift From Latest Stimulus Checks
summary: McDonald's owners, Checkers, TGI Fridays and others report January boost-but the lift can be fleeting.

title: Tyson Foods to Settle Price-Fixing Claims
summary: Meat company to pay $221.5 million to poultry buyers, helping end a fight over alleged collusion. Tyson Foods Inc. said it has agreed to pay $221.5 million to settle with plaintiff groups of poultry buyers that sued it for price-fixing claims, helping resolve a four-year legal battle over alleged collusion in the $65 billion chicken industry.

title: A Biden Tax-Hike Break for Small Businesses
summary: Congress should raise the top corporate rate to 28%, but only for the most profitable companies.. With President Biden in office and Democrats controlling the Senate, you can expect the new administration to propose a new tax bill soon, including an increase in the corporate tax rate to 28% from 21%.

title: No, You Can't Try an Impeached Former President
summary: The Senate erroneously asserted jurisdiction once, but dissenting members forced an acquittal.. Now that Donald Trump is a private citizen, the Senate should dismiss the article of impeachment against him for lack of jurisdiction. The Constitution is clear: "The president . . . shall be removed from office on impeachment . . . and conviction"-not by the expiration of his term before the impeachment process is complete. It also mandates that "judgment in cases of impeachment shall not extend further than to removal and disqualification"-not or disqualification.

title: 'The Kaiser of Atlantis' and 'Mezzo Extravaganza' Reviews: Outdoor Opera Resonates
summary: Now available to watch online, the Atlanta Opera's in-person performances embraced Covid-19 restrictions as a creative challenge..

title: Russian Gold Miner Nordgold Aims to List in $5 Billion London IPO
summary: Possible offering comes amid a monthslong rally in precious-metal prices. Russian gold miner Nord Gold UK Societas, or Nordgold, is looking to list in London as early as this summer, capitalizing on the precious metal's long price run to become the largest mining company to float globally in at least five years, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Trump Leaves Washington the Way He Entered-as a Political Outsider
summary: President departed with ties to Republican leaders strained and his political prospects unclear. WASHINGTON-Donald Trump began his presidency as a Washington outsider and is ending it as one, with his future political prospects and influence diminished by his unsuccessful campaign to overturn his election loss.

title: Composting Has Gone High-Tech
summary: We tried out four new ways to encourage rot that are easier, chicer and far less smelly than the hippy methods of old. HUMANS HAVE composted food for about as long as they have grown it. But in a world increasingly obsessed with tidy convenience, many view the chore of converting food waste into fertilizer for plants and gardens much as they do tending to kombucha scoby or committing to cloth diapers for their infants: too time-consuming, too "granola" and too plain icky.

title: Jay-Z to Boost Minority-Owned Cannabis Businesses
summary: Rapper creates $10 million fund for startups, saying people of color have missed out on marijuana boom. Jay-Z is launching a fund to invest in minority-owned cannabis startups to bolster Black participation in the industry.

title: The Next Stop for Departing Public Officials? Hollywood
summary: From Beto O'Rourke and Stacey Abrams to John Kasich, politicians and bureaucrats are looking for another close up. When Beto O'Rourke dropped out of the Democratic primary, analysts speculated on the Texas politician's future on the national stage. For help navigating it, Mr. O'Rourke turned to Creative Artists Agency, the Hollywood talent agency known for shaping the careers of Beyoncé and Brad Pitt.

title: Sixth Street Partners to Acquire Life Insurance Business Talcott Resolution for $2 Billion
summary: Financial firms continue to scoop up life-insurance policies and annuities. Financial firm Sixth Street Partners has agreed to buy annuities company Talcott Resolution for $2 billion, the latest ownership change in a decade of frenzied industrywide life-insurance deal activity.

title: Woodcock to Lead FDA on Interim Basis
summary: Longtime head of drug-review efforts to take over agency after its turbulent year dealing with Covid-19 pandemic. WASHINGTON-Janet Woodcock, who has led the Food and Drug Administration's drug review efforts for years, is slated to oversee the agency on an interim basis after current Commissioner Stephen Hahn leaves Wednesday.

title: Trump Pardons 74, Including Former Aide Steve Bannon
summary: Recipients include former GOP fundraiser Elliott Broidy and rapper Lil Wayne. President Trump issued a flurry of pardons and commutations on his final day in office, rewarding a handful of longtime allies and well-connected celebrities, including his former chief strategist, Steve Bannon, and onetime fundraiser Elliott Broidy.

title: Morgan Stanley Profit Shoots Higher, Fueled by Wall Street
summary: Fourth-quarter earnings jumped 51%; results topped analyst estimates. Morgan Stanley said fourth-quarter profit rose 51% from a year earlier, another big U.S. bank to emerge from a turbulent year in better shape than was expected at the onset of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Procter & Gamble Gets Shoppers to Pay Up
summary: Sales jumped 8% in latest quarter, fueled by demand for high-end household products. Procter & Gamble Co. sales surged in the most recent quarter, fueled in part by demand for high-end household products from pricey dish soap to a $300 electric toothbrush.

title: Why the Director of Netflix's 'White Tiger' Is Drawn to an Unscrupulous Underdog
summary: Ramin Bahrani, who brought his friend's prize-winning novel to the screen, is intrigued by characters who 'aren't typically written about or movies aren't made about.'. Aravind Adiga's Man Booker Prize-winning novel, "The White Tiger," was published in 2008 but Ramin Bahrani began to see drafts four years earlier. He and the author had been friends since they were students at Columbia University and regularly shared manuscripts and screenplays. Mr. Bahrani, the director of movies including "Chop Shop" and "Man Push Cart," was blown away by the story of Balram Halwai, who goes to work as a driver for a rich Indian family and charts a violent path out of poverty.

title: Biden's Dogs Shepherd In New Era of Pets at the White House
summary: Resume Subscription. On Jan. 17, the Delaware Humane Association held a virtual "indoguration" for Major, Joe Biden's three-year-old German shepherd, who was adopted from the animal shelter in 2018. The Zoom event drew over 7,400 attendees and their pets, raised some $200,000 to benefit the association, and featured a performance by Josh Groban, who sang a slightly altered rendition of "How Much is that Doggie in the Window."

title: Justice Department Seeks to Limit Scope of LGBT Rights Decision
summary: New directive, aimed at a 2020 Supreme Court ruling, comes in the waning moments of the Trump administration. WASHINGTON-The Justice Department has issued a memo that aims to limit the impact of a landmark Supreme Court ruling protecting gay and transgender people in the workplace, a last-ditch attempt from the Trump administration to hinder policy shifts expected as President-elect Joe Biden begins assembling new leadership at the agency.

title: Presidential Pups
summary: The White House has gone to the dogs.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: How to Turn Your Sad Laundry Closet Into a Laundry Room
summary: Even if you're washing your clothes in a cluttered crawl space, our columnist's guidance will help you achieve the laundry nook of your dreams.. IN MY DREAMS, my laundry room is airy and bright, with wooden folding tables and shelves with baskets to intelligently organize detergents, sewing supplies, my ironing board and clothespins. In other words, it would resemble a modest-size Apple store, except with a whole section devoted to orphan socks.

title: UnitedHealth's Profit Slips as Health-Care Visits Return
summary: The company paid more in medical costs to cover insured members who returned to doctors' offices after delaying care earlier in the pandemic. UnitedHealth Group Inc. recorded a smaller profit for the last quarter of 2020 as the company saw rising medical costs tied to Covid-19.

title: Outdoor Dining Menus Heat Up With Comfort Foods
summary: New York City restaurants add steaming hot meals to warm customers during winter months. New York City restaurants have always added a few hearty dishes to their menus come winter. But now that they are limited to serving customers outdoors because of the coronavirus pandemic, the focus on such fare has become almost mandatory, if not an obsession.

title: Trump Rescinds Own Lobby Ban
summary: Outgoing president strikes down his order that had blocked administration officials from taking lobbying jobs for five years after leaving office. WASHINGTON-In one of his final acts in office, President Trump on Wednesday rescinded rules he created four years ago that he said at the time would make his government one of the most ethical in U.S. history.

title: P&G Has Topped Out for Now
summary: Rich valuation and the fact that shares aren't likely to shine in a pandemic recovery are holding company back. Everything is going Procter & Gamble 's way. Investors should ask whether this is as good as it gets for a while.

title: Australians Can't Get Home, but Tennis Players Fly in From Covid-19 Hot Spots
summary: Athletes arrive as country reduces the number of international arrivals allowed. SYDNEY-International tennis stars jetted into Australia last week from some of the world's worst coronavirus hot spots. At the same time, ordinary Australians were prohibited from traveling between the country's two biggest cities because of a small outbreak in one of them.

title: Peter Huber Provoked Debate on Medicine, the Environment
summary: Harvard-trained lawyer and author, who has died at age 68, taught thermodynamics at MIT before diving into public policy. By age 23, Peter W. Huber had a Ph.D. in mechanical engineering and was teaching thermodynamics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. To keep his mind sufficiently occupied, he enrolled at Harvard Law School and shuttled by moped between teaching classes at MIT and taking them at Harvard.

title: Biden Will Lead an Older, Polarized and Financially Insecure Nation
summary: U.S. has weaker economy, shorter life expectancy and voters who have moved toward the edges of both parties. President Joe Biden will lead a country with an aging population that is on shakier economic footing and is more politically polarized than at most points in recent years.

title: Netflix, Gevo, Morgan Stanley: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Earnings season continues apace as the White House changes hands. -U.S. stock futures gained ahead of a busy day of earnings reports and the inauguration of Joe Biden as the 46th president.

title: Meet Critic Lauren Oyler: The Literary World's Provocateur Releases a Debut Novel
summary: Book reviewer Lauren Oyler, known for her takedowns, has written her own inventive tale about the internet and the nature of identity, 'Fake Accounts'. "Whenever I write anything, I'm always afraid that I'm going to get in trouble somehow," says Lauren Oyler. The literary critic, whose work appears in the New Yorker and the London Review of Books, is on Zoom from Ithaca, New York. She is speaking from a high-ceilinged, "not-New-York-sized" apartment she moved to in August to be near Cornell University, where her boyfriend is a fellow. The sort of trouble you can get into reviewing books is pretty negligible, but on social media, where Oyler's unsparing takedowns of books by popular authors are hotly discussed, dynamics of jealousy and adulation are heightened. Books she has covered include Roxane Gay's Bad Feminist; Kristen Roupenian's short-story collection, You Know You Want This (the much-hyped follow-up to her New Yorker story "Cat Person"); and, infamously, New Yorker staff writer Jia Tolentino's essay collection Trick Mirror. Oyler's pitiless review crashed the London Review of Books website shortly after posting. On Twitter , Tolentino commented that it had been "a cleansing, illuminating experience to be read with such open disgust!"

title: Mountain of Small Loans Looms Over Europe's Banks
summary: Banks have outsize exposure to small businesses, the backbone of the continent's economy. If these businesses fail, pain awaits Europe's already-stretched lenders.. Miguel Ríos had a bustling business running four karaoke bars in Barcelona until the coronavirus forced him to shut them. He took out bank loans worth €80,000, equivalent to $96,000, put his 10 employees on a government wage-support program and hoped for the best.

title: What Time Does Biden's Inauguration Start? A Viewer's Guide From How to Watch to the Schedule of Events
summary: Organizers have planned a mix of in-person and virtual events for the start of Joe Biden's presidency. President-elect Joe Biden's inauguration today will look different than past presidents' because of the coronavirus pandemic. Organizers have planned a mix of in-person and virtual events for the start of his presidency.

title: What to Expect on Trump's Final Day in Office
summary: The president won't attend Joe Biden's inauguration but will participate in a send-off at Joint Base Andrews. WASHINGTON-A president's final day in office typically includes a front-row seat at the inauguration and a formal meeting with his successor. But President Trump is doing things his own way.

title: Can Biden Avoid Obama's First-Term Mistake?
summary: The left will try to convince the new president he has a mandate for progressive change. He doesn't.. When Barack Obama and Joe Biden entered the White House 12 years ago, the economy was in recession, unemployment was pushing 8%, and their fellow Democrats controlled the House and Senate. Sound familiar?

title: Investor FOMO Is Selective for Luxury Brands
summary: Burberry's turnaround plans are seen as less convincing than a similar push at Prada. Investors don't want to miss out on the luxury sector's next Gucci-style brand turnaround. Still, their strong preference for Prada SpA over Burberry Group, both of which are in the middle of revamps, is a puzzle.

title: Governors Island Rezoning Plan Faces Pushback
summary: Proposal calls for a climate-research hub that would allow 4.5 million square feet of new commercial development on the island. Since 2003, Governors Island, the 172-acre island in New York Harbor, has been transformed from a former military base into a summertime recreational oasis. However, the next phase of the island's development and rezoning is facing resistance.

title: Stocks Could Plunge Even if the Economy Booms
summary: Can we face a bear market even if the economy booms? Yes, but it would be rare.. We keep being reminded that the stock market isn't the economy. But then, is it possible for the market to go into a long bear run even if the economy booms? Yes, although there is little record of it ever happening.

title: What the Blue Wave Means for Green Goals
summary: A Democratic majority in both chambers of Congress, even with narrow margins, could open the door to some potentially transformative clean-energy policies. The narrow Democratic Party majority in Congress might close the door on some of President-elect Joe Biden's most ambitious clean-energy proposals, but it opens one up for tax-policy changes. That alone could supercharge the industry.

title: Jack Ma, Alibaba's Co-Founder, Resurfaces After Months of Lying Low
summary: The appearance was his first since regulators began clamping down on his business empire. Embattled billionaire Jack Ma made his first public appearance in nearly three months, speaking via a video link at a philanthropic event on Wednesday, easing speculation about his safety and whereabouts.

title: China Escalates Efforts to Beat Back Its Worst Covid-19 Resurgence
summary: Northern cities build temporary quarantine facilities, impose lockdown measures on millions of residents and roll out mass testing. HONG KONG-Chinese health authorities have ramped up their efforts to contain a resurgence of coronavirus cases, as the country faces its worst flare-up since the pandemic first exploded there early last year.

title: Hong Kong Stocks Swell as Market Eats Up Chinese Cash
summary: The city's stock market is at a 20-month high, and trading volumes have hit records thanks to mainland investors. Hong Kong shares have surged to a 20-month high, and trading volumes have hit records, as investors from mainland China have jumped into the market in search of bargains and stocks not available back home.

title: 5G's Huge Upfront Bill Will Come Due
summary: Spectrum auction will cost carriers about $95 billion, but payoff is uncertain. Wireless carriers clearly believe their own press about 5G. And they are wagering a huge sum to prove it.

title: How Covid-19 Vaccine Rollouts Will Pump Through Global Markets
summary: Markets where vaccines are rolled out rapidly may be beneficiaries, but the greater impact could be on the laggards. The rollout of Covid-19 vaccines is finally under way. Markets are already showing that the speed of local rollouts matters quite a bit-but global vaccination campaigns will also ripple through financial markets in some unexpected ways, including in places that have successfully controlled the disease.

title: Companies Revisit Forecasts Ahead of Potential Tax Changes
summary: Higher tax rates, new incentives and penalties could impact business costs under the Biden administration. Companies are ramping up their financial forecasting and planning to prepare for potential changes to the U.S. tax code under the incoming Biden administration, which are more likely after Georgia's runoff elections handed Democrats control of the Senate.

title: Commercial Real Estate Debt Sustained by Bond Buying
summary: Some are concerned that policy is obscuring potential long-term pain inflicted by Covid-19 lockdowns.

title: AstraZeneca Vaccine Speeds U.K. Effort to Reach Nursing Homes
summary: The shot, yet to be approved elsewhere in the West, is easier to store, ship and administer to recipients unable to travel. LONDON-The coronavirus has torn through nursing homes in the U.K., as it has in the U.S., taking tens of thousands of lives. Now, the U.K. hopes it is turning the tide, thanks to a homegrown vaccine that has yet to be authorized elsewhere in the West.

title: Americans Aren't Draining Their Retirement Funds in the Pandemic
summary: The number of people taking early withdrawals related to Covid-19 is lower than expected. Workers affected by the pandemic continued to withdraw money from their retirement accounts in the final months of 2020. But, as happened earlier in the year, the increase in the number of people taking withdrawals was modest.

title: Slow Vaccine Distribution Adds to Tokyo Olympics Woes
summary: Lagging vaccinations in the U.S. and a skeptical Japanese public complicate the Games, now six months away. Organizers of the Tokyo Olympics face a long list of obstacles as they attempt to carry off the postponed Games in six months-and the alarming rise in Covid cases around the world recently is only one of them.

title: McConnell Says Trump Provoked Mob That Attacked Capitol
summary: Senate majority leader also seeks to protect filibuster as Democrats take control of the chamber. WASHINGTON-Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell for the first time publicly cast blame on President Trump for the violent attack on the Capitol earlier this month as he moved to try to preserve Republican sway in the Senate on the final day of the party's majority status.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Filibuster Rule Snarls Senate Power-Sharing Deal
summary: McConnell and Schumer negotiate rules for 50-50 chamber as it prepares to take up Biden's cabinet nominees and likely impeachment trial. WASHINGTON-Negotiations over how to organize a Senate evenly divided along party lines have snagged on the fate of the legislative filibuster, a longstanding rule that empowers the minority party to block most bills.

title: U.S. Says China Is Committing Genocide Against Uighurs
summary: State Department cites imprisonment, torture and forced sterilization against minority group, accusations Beijing has denied. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration concluded that China has committed "genocide and crimes against humanity" against the Uighur ethnic group, delivering a forceful condemnation to Beijing over a mass repression campaign that has yet to prompt tough international action.

title: Trump Approves Deportation Protections for Venezuelans in U.S. Illegally
summary: The action comes under the Deferred Enforced Departure program that offers deportation protections and work permits to immigrants in the country without authorization. WASHINGTON-As one of his final acts in office, President Trump has authorized a program to give work permits and deportation protections to Venezuelan immigrants in the U.S. without legal permission, an action President-elect Joe Biden had promised to take during the 2020 campaign.

title: NASA Mulls A New Deep-Space Rocket Test Despite Technical Concerns
summary: Repeating Saturday's aborted ground test could unduly stress booster prior to liftoff. NASA is wrestling with the decision whether to redo ground checks of a mammoth deep-space rocket's main engines, which prematurely shut off during an aborted test Saturday.

title: Biden's Agenda for His First 100 Days
summary: Resume Subscription. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden takes office this week with a far-reaching set of plans for his first 100 days, but he must grapple with narrow Democratic majorities in Congress and an unsettled country as he seeks to roll back some of his Republican predecessor's policies and curb the pandemic.

title: No Charges After Inquiry Into Senator's Stock Trades
summary: Transactions were made by North Carolina lawmaker in advance of Covid-19 market turmoil last year. The Justice Department won't pursue charges against GOP Sen. Richard Burr after ending its investigation of stock trades he made in advance of the coronavirus market turmoil last year, the North Carolina lawmaker said.

title: DHS Pick Mayorkas Says He Would Work to Thwart Another Capitol Attack
summary: Republican objection to fast-tracking Biden's nominee suggests he won't be confirmed on first day of administration. WASHINGTON-Alejandro Mayorkas, President-elect Joe Biden's pick for Homeland Security secretary, told a Senate hearing Tuesday he would work to ensure that an attack like the Jan. 6 riot at the Capitol wouldn't be repeated, though his confirmation by Inauguration Day appeared to be delayed.

title: Wimkin Removed From Google Play
summary: Takedown follows the removal of the small social-media network from Apple's App Store last week. Alphabet Inc.'s Google has removed the small social-media site Wimkin from its Google Play store, joining Apple Inc. in cutting the app's reach amid a broader effort to rein in misleading or potentially harmful content.

title: PPP Reopens With 60,000 Loans for Small Businesses
summary: First wave of applications is largely handled by community and small lenders after SBA set aside time for them to act exclusively. Roughly 60,000 borrowers were approved for more than $5 billion in forgivable loans during the first week of the reopened Paycheck Protection Program, the Small Business Administration said Tuesday.

title: Biden's Inauguration Speech to Emphasize American Unity
summary: Outdoor address before empty National Mall will be secured by 25,000 National Guard troops after Trump supporters stormed Capitol. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden, taking office at a time of national crisis, plans to emphasize themes of unity and recovery in his inaugural address, messages that he returned to repeatedly on the campaign trail on his way to victory over President Trump.

title: Outgoing FCC Chief Says Government Laid Groundwork for Faster Networks
summary: Ajit Pai says he focused on fostering investment while maintaining independence. Ajit Pai's four years atop the Federal Communications Commission outlasted many senior officials in the Trump administration where tenure was often measured in months.

title: Blinken Backs Tough Approach to China, Says Will Work With GOP
summary: Biden's pick for secretary of state also lauds Abraham Accords, backs recognition of Guaidó in Venezuela. WASHINGTON-President-elect Joe Biden's pick for secretary of state backed a tough approach to China and found common ground with Republicans on issues ranging from Israel to Venezuela, hinting at a more unified approach to foreign policy in the next four years.

title: Netflix Tops 200 Million Subscribers for the First Time
summary: Streaming giant said it added a record 37 million subscribers in 2020. Netflix Inc. ended last year with more than 200 million subscribers, a milestone powered by consumers left homebound by the pandemic, eager for entertainment, and rising demand in international markets where the streaming giant has a head start over many rivals.
